title: Friday, 30th November 2018
bodyHTML:
11:12 am
BE11:13am

Yes, yes. I know. But it's a Friday and it's more or less 11am so, honestly, you have no grounds to complain.

Markkus morning all
VV75 morning
BE11:13am

This is ML, FTAV's etc

MassimoJ Morning
Soundbuy Morning
DogDay morning
BE11:14am

All eyes on Buenos Aires, of course.

PBateman Morning
11:15 am
BE11:15am

Waiting so see what nonsense Trump and says to Xi Jinping.

BE11:15am

And while we wait, we're down. FTSE off 0.7% at pixel.

red nonsense that flows of billions will be based on. but TINA
Tom Dalgleish If Xi was a cricketer he’d be Ken Barrington
BE11:17am

Europe off 0.3 to 0.7% or thereabouts, and it's pretty difficult to put a headline trend on it.

11:17 am
BE11:17am

So ..... let's not bother. Market reporting's all bunk anyway.

undefined
jaws gm
BE11:18am

.... and let's head straight into corporate.

OllieR50 Morning
11:18 am
BE11:18am

Have we mentioned Amigo much here before?

Amigo Holdings PLC (AMGO:LSE): Last: 245.60, down 17.6 (-6.69%), High: 275.00, Low: 245.05, Volume: 31.11k
BE11:19am

It's a curious business. Essentially a subprime lender that sinks your mates as well as you.

11:19 am
BE11:19am

Website's an adventure ......

BE11:20am

https://www.amigoplc.com/about/history

Tom Dalgleish Never lend to a friend
BE11:20am

Before the 1970s banks would make lending decisions based on relationships and trust. If someone wanted a loan their local bank would often simply ask for someone who trusted them to guarantee it. Then things changed, computer credit scores took over and people found they were unable to access credit via traditional lending because their score didn’t fit.

Soundbuy Don't reckon their advertising agency would run with that.............
FATDAZ Good morning
11:20 am
BE11:21am

Damn those computers with their credit scoring. Banking was much better when you went to see a rotund guy in a double-breasted suit and begged him.

BE11:21am

Anyway, Amigo tends to be a bit ignored because there's not much free float. Founder James Benamor still has 60% or so.

BornCynic Morning BE - how can I complain? This is free (always a good price).
FATDAZ @tomdalgliesh I have to admit I had to look him up
BE11:22am

,,,, though how long he'll hold that stake once the lockup comes off is something we'll find out quite soon.

Tom Dalgleish @Fatty, in the days when cricket meant more, he was more Boycott than Boycott
11:23 am
BE11:23am

Anyway, Amigo has an 88% market share of guarantor loans and charges -- you ready for this? -- 49.9% representative APR

BE11:23am

Max loan £10,000 over 12 to 60 months

VV75 49,9??? holy moly
BornCynic I have seen the adverts on TV and the APR is not pretty
FATDAZ @tom thanks
Viking1 Morning , by the going rate there will be no banks left in Europe who are indicated to have been involved in Danske laundry operation
BornCynic Not as bad as some of the 1,500% lot though............
1st Lt. Fletcher Christian "It's a curious business. Essentially a subprime lender that sinks your mates as well as you." LOL
Viking1 Who are NOT indicated ...
BE11:24am

Why am I telling you all this? Well, it's because Goodbody has a big note out this morning on the UK subprimes.

jaws Anything in Volex please ?
11:24 am
BE11:25am

And they reckon Amigo's running out of road.

BE11:25am

AMGO is the clear market leader in UK guarantor lending and has enjoyed a period of exceptional growth – which has seen its loan book expand from £272m at end-FY15 to almost £700m at end-1H18. However, while we see management deliver on its high-teens and mid-teens net loan growth for FY18F and FY19F, we see asubstantial slowdown thereafter as the scope to keep increasing its addressable market becomes more challenging – with redemptions remaining elevated following a supernormal growth phase. We also project rising, though manageable, impairments owing to its pilot lending experience and risks associated with repeat lending dependency and higher average loans.

VV75 volume traded is very low indeed
Lemmy It was only floated in June
BE11:26am

This thing was floated in June, right?

Lemmy sorry, July
11:26 am
BE11:26am

We value AMGO at just 7.5x FY20F earnings due to the substantial slowdown in loan book and eps growth we see starting to quickly take hold from FY20F despite the opportunity to leverage up further at that point. 15% discount rate to account for company-specific risks. TP 204p. Valuation looks stretched. SELL.

1st Lt. Fletcher Christian Another Woodford holding.
red seems to be another bring to mkt as an end game rather than view to expand
Tom Dalgleish ......trying to find an activity that needs quick, short term finance....
BornCynic I'm going to take a risk here - anything in your inbox on Allied Minds please BE. Past history has nothing to do with the question - it's up 30% today.........
nichoman @jaws. volex been doing well. haven't looked at it for ages. what's changed there ? always seemed to me like it would be better owned by asian manufacturer and with lower cost
BE11:28am

Already sub the 275p issue price. And if memory serves, it was an exit for Benamor and the other directors rather than new funds.

BE11:29am

Richmond -- as in Benamor's holding company -- said it didn't want board representation in early September.

red uk property still feeling the blues from yest i see. all the usuals are dwn
11:29 am
BE11:30am

And he resigned as a director later that month. So, let's face it, the chances of a secondary soon after the lockups come off is approximately 100%.

BE11:30am

Anyway. That's Amigo.

undefined
red you wonder when will folks learn
FATDAZ @red very topical given comments made earlier in the weeks about lakeside tenants , Intu and rents
11:31 am
BE11:31am

Urg, Allied bloody Minds .......

Shinshin AMigo is actually assesing the credit of the guarantor, no ? Who could presumably go and get a loan at not-sub-prime rates, and lend that to their amigo.
BornCynic Aplogies BE.
Airborne Cigar @Tom Dalgleish - I think KB's strike rate was abit higher that Boycott's - the criticism was always that in teams with the likes of Graveney and Dexter and Cowdrey, he wasn't stylish enough...
red @redintu and more brexit blues. but...lokks like it may well be better to travel than arrive on some of these.
wayneJ @BornCynic - just catching up - are you not confusing price and value. The price of FTAV ML is free; the value of BE ranting is substanially more. I suspect you intended to say that there is a substanial margin of safety in your daily consumption of FTAV ML? (My inner 'value investor' trying to escape).
BornCynic I could ask about utilities if you prefer..........
red pretty much like post ref. we'll see how far they drop into first tho.
BE11:32am

Bouncing 33% on no news and not a pot of volume ......

Tom Dalgleish @Airborne, stodgy but effective
Tom Dalgleish JRM would be Cowdrey
Plato the Cook Gone are the days of “don’t be short (wink)”
wayneJ Isn't Allied Minds share price responding to Jefferies conversion on the road to Damacus to 'spin memories'. I seem to recall that the spin memory sector has a number of skeletons along the sides of that particular road.
wayneJ See https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spin-transfer_torque
wayneJ But I am sure IBM also once worked in that area?
BE11:35am

In terms of relevant news, I'd assume this is on Everspin's recent numbers and the chances of it raising more cash.

11:35 am
BE11:35am

@wayneJ reminds us of the recent Jefferies note here .....

1st Lt. Fletcher Christian I wouldn't touch Allied Minds. Like buying a tin of spaghetti.
BornCynic @wayneJ - BE does not rant - he provides insightful analysis :)
wayneJ But sell side not employed to use Prof Google and Prof Wikipedia - or have the age to remember stuff.
BE11:36am

Delays amid an otherwise hot MRAM sector had us doubting Spin Memory could complete its funding even with an 80% down round. The outcome was around 50% down (est) and with stellar partners AMAT & Arm: supports SM’s value at 21p/FD ALM share with equally well validated Fed Wireless/HawkEye/BridgeSat another 41p, and funding burden is off ALM’s shoulders. Even with a 50% markdown to the biotechs, our PT is 99p and we upgrade to Buy.

BE11:36am

Which, to emphasise, was from November 13.

11:37 am
BE11:37am

With the SM news above, Allied Minds now has major validating investors in four of its top six portfolio companies (SM above; Federated Wireless with Charter Comms, American Tower, Arris; HawkEye360 Raytheon, Sumitomo and BridgeSat Boeing). While we continue to be cautious over the two major healthcare holdings (SciFluor, Precision Biopsy) the tech story is increasingly well supported versus the close to all-time low share price. With cash at the parent of $66m at end June 2018 and the tech cos all funded/supported externally, the downside even if the biotechs fail is surely now limited (our downside case with them written off completely and all cash expended is 64p/share).

Tom Dalgleish 3D Magnetic memories have always been a mirage
wayneJ @BornCynic - one man's rant is another man's insightful analysis :-) [Though I suspect for regulatory reasons in a post MIFID II world if I 'accepted' it was analysis I would be obligated to send cheques to BE.]
wayneJ This was what i was looking for (after a slight diversion to the Mineral Resource Authority of Mongolia = MRAM !) ----https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Magnetoresistive_random-access_memory
BE11:39am

None of which answers why it's up 33% this morning. And for the answer to that I suspect ADVFN or London-South-East are better places to look.

Tom Dalgleish BE would bat the middle order. Eye always in. 1’s and 2’s
undefined
11:39 am
BE11:39am

While we're on irritating stuff ........

Viking1 Do they hold Spin Memory ,
Fevertree Drinks PLC (FEVR:LSE): Last: 2,436, up 94 (+4.01%), High: 2,477, Low: 2,378, Volume: 204.79k
BE11:39am

Bounce.

11:39 am
BE11:40am

Largely on the back of Nielsen data which suggests that nothing dramatic's gone wrong.

wayneJ Ah! ADVFN and LSE - what is the collective noun for places where people rant? (A 'parliament of punters'?)
BE11:40am

But also on the back of broker comment, of the type that tends to be generated by a quiet call to IR to ask "hey, so why no trading statement?"

red advfn iii hemscott ofex oh the dotcom days
BE11:41am

Morgan Stanley summarises .....

11:41 am
BE11:41am

4th November 2015 - "materially ahead of expectations"
7th November 2016 - "materially ahead of current market expectations"
7th November 2017 - "materially ahead of current market expectations"
November 2018 - ... no statement.

BE11:41am

Yep, but so what?

BE11:41am

General disclosures of price sensitive information, covered by AIM rule 11 and Article 17 of MAR, requires companies to make a notification of developments that would likely lead to a significant movement in the price of AIM listed securities. This would include matters concerning change in performance of business or expectations of performance. There is nothing in AIM or MAR that specifies what a constitutes a “significant” move, but our understanding is that the "10% rule" would apply in this situation. Current consensus is £223m which implies the company is not required to issue a trading update unless they expect revenue of more than £245m (MSe £227.8). Despite no trading update, there is still plenty of scope for a upgrades/a beat on FY18 results and we feel confident into numbers.

BornCynic Wow ADVFN lists a lot of crypto currencies on its front page.
11:43 am
BE11:43am

This isn't the first time in recent sessions that we've talked about the 10% rule, is it? To summarise: it's not a rule. It's just a protocol.

BE11:43am

Anyway, back to Nielsen. And Jefferies.

BornCynic Anyway - thanks for that BE
BE11:43am

Nielsen data for four weeks to 4/11/18 shows FEVR growth +31.8% vs previous month +37.4%. If this level of growth continues, 2H UK growth will likely be +40%-50% (vs Jef +20%) after 1H +73%, providing c.8% upside risk to our top-line estimates.

Airborne Cigar @Tom Dalgleish - not sure BE's style would work at T20 - he's more Tavare in his prime, I think...
11:44 am
BE11:44am

This is all post Schweppes relaunching for the umpteenth time, and Suntory's Merchant's Heart trying to carve out a place behind the bar.

BE11:45am

Schweppes did 23.2% growth BTW.

BE11:45am

Although Fever-Tree has not published a “unscheduled trading update” as many had expected, the company's tone remains confident. The company is still growing ahead of the category and a normalization of growth was always expected. H2 run rate robust, 31% growth for a category leader in the UK is still very positive and in absolute terms sales are growing on a monthly basis. Merchant heart is still very small, all other brands (excl. Schweppes and own label) account for c.4% of category.

wayneJ 'Punters' on LSE are quoting someone on twitter..... but that is a dark hole where Allied Minds, Almirall and Alliance Mining share the same code leading to confusion....
Airborne Cigar ... or maybe Brian Hardie
FATDAZ @airborne one of may favs
FATDAZ my favs even
Viking1 PS , the nil paids on RTN marvellous Just like the old days Sorry , thought you should knowOrd up 8%
BornCynic FT made the Guardian again yesterday - are things OK there BE?
11:47 am
BE11:48am

So just checked Ocado. There's Fevertree or Fentimans or Schweppes or Britvic or London Essence of 1783 or Lamb & Watt or Double Dutch or Peter Spanton or Folkingtons or Harvey Nicks or Bermondey Tonic or own brand.

BE11:48am

And I genuinely don't care which I get. Perhaps I'm just uncultured.

undefined
11:48 am
BE11:48am

(@BornCynic: I'm in my element, thanks.)

BE11:49am

Viking mentions the Restaurant Group nil-paids .....

rw42 I like gin and tonic. I'm not too picky about which, as long as there are no artificial sweeteners involved.
BE11:50am

Which are up ..... heh ..... 23%? Because ................ um ....................

11:50 am
Restaurant Group PLC (RTN:LSE): Last: 145.80, up 11.4 (+8.48%), High: 146.90, Low: 135.10, Volume: 587.37k
FATDAZ @rw42 I can almost hear the hiss of the tonic bottle
Viking1 Exactly ,FridayHowever , Wagamama to run the entire show ?
wayneJ @BE - the other day you claimed never to have been to a Greggs; now not caring about what mixer. Rather than say you are 'uncultured' I would humbly suggest you are 'sensible' - and know what really matters.
wayneJ Did anyone work out what the PM was on about yesterday during her cross-examination by parliamentary committee - if I understood correctly she is assuming that the EU will not cut Freedom of Movement for Brits going into the EU despite the UK cutting FoM for Europeans coming to the UK???? Did I understand that right?
BE11:53am

So the ordinaries go up and down based on the churn of the shareholder list from income to ... um, let's call it "growth" I guess .... and the nils just amplify that?

BE11:54am

Have Canaccord anyway.

11:54 am
BE11:54am

We have used a sum-of-the-parts methodology to determine our 190p (post rights issue) share price target. We have used our FY19E forecasts and we retained the Wagamama valuation at £560m which backs out a 9.9x EBITDA multiple. We have used SSPG as a proxy to value Concessions and referenced Brunning & Price to average pubco multiples, even though every pubco would love to own this division. We have applied a 5x EBITDA multiple to the Leisure division. Delivery and Food-to-go initiatives are free options. At TERP, TRG is valued at 11.1x PE, 6.8x EV/EBITDA and 10.7% for FY19E, changing to 8.9x, 5.8x and 13.4% for FY20E. Despite the new dividend policy (2x cover) the yield for FY19E of 4.5% helps to pass the time as management starts work on delivering its plan.

wayneJ Was not sure if it was an example of British exceptionalism or just bizarre. Would have thought it has massive implications for tour operators? (Reminder we discussed Thomas Cook earlier in week)
FATDAZ re G&T on our last trip to mallorca i sampled a range of gins as pre dinner drinks and surprisingly I found I favoured Beefeater above the artisan drinks
RuminationsOn 're RTN - Brough pushed them yesterday at So in FWIW. And I'm not going to publicly dismissive
Viking1 Suggestions that the shareholders who voted through RTN had certain conditions attached to this decision , Just being Friday I guess
BE11:55am

Jamie tells me the Broughy was at Sohn yesterday and pitched Restaurant Group.

RuminationsOn Autocorrect Sohn
BE11:55am

I assume as a long, since Schroders is a 10% holder.

wayneJ Also what % home country rules will airlines based in the UK have? (IAG already moving - but wondering if the UK will have any domestic airlines left?)
PerhapsNotMyRealNameThisTime he was very excited about concessions and delivery...
11:56 am
BE11:56am

Whatever. We're in the tail-swallowing phase of the process so prices are nearly irrelevant.

BE11:56am

Fully paids start 14 December.

undefined
Viking1 WayneJ , story from FFT , Merkel offering twice the org amount for certain migrant to leave
FATDAZ @BE apropo nothing I started out in a new issues dept back in 1984
Viking1 WayneJ ...should be plural
RAVER what's the Broughy at Sohn?
11:58 am
BE11:59am

(@Fatdaz: Beefeater's good gin. It's all about the tails. I could do an hour on moonshine one of these days. Ditch this stocks stuff.)

Lemmy Andy Brough, mid cap fund manager
wayneJ @Viking1 - interesting.
nichoman Spirits Live
BE11:59am

Anything else? Kinda quiet today.

BE11:59am

There's this.

VV75 Happy hour
12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

nichoman ooooh he looks very dodgy
cloudy @Fatdaz - I seem to remember partly-paid rights issue shares. Don't hear that these days.
Flaneur Director pads out numbers in advance of sale. Colour me stunned...
FATDAZ @BE perhaps a live event an evening with Bryce Elder.....
FATDAZ @cloudy yes a call in installments
BE12:01pm

And I'm sure there will be some glasses raised tonight for the US prosecutor among London's technology analysis community.

FATDAZ @ BE an FTAV betnoir
Flaneur @fatdaz - yeah like the canadian fellow and the chat show host... Call it 'Elders Whimsy'
red plenty of dodgy accting as far as tech sector goes, would be surprised if this is anything more than sour grapes. tech values go down as well as up.
BE12:02pm

The US indictment accuses Mr Lynch and Mr Chamberlain of “artificially inflating revenues” [by] backdating transactions in order to report sales early, booking revenues that were subject to “round-trip” agreements that saw the money returned to the customer and failing to properly apply all the tests in both international and US accounting standards for when revenue should be recognised.

Flaneur Could talk about anything. Gin, Scotland, Brexit, Shares, Bonds, Brexit...
FATDAZ It always felt that HP were overpaying at the time
12:03 pm
BE12:03pm

If only someone had mentioned this when Frank Quattrone was shopping the pitchbook to anyone who's listen?

BE12:03pm

Oh, hang on, lots and lots of people did.

FATDAZ @flanneur could be very entertaining if a bit niche
undefined
red most tech buyouts are premium but while the music still plays...
wayneJ @BE - an interesting question is why did HP not pull the deal? At least some of 'London's technology analysis community' has claimed that they warned HP either by (e)mail or in person? Also as a sophisticated buyer what was the extent of HP's financial DD? And why was Cathy (the CFO) overriden?
Viking1 Did you see the latest data breach, Marriott Hotells , 500 mill affected , huge data breach
red @Viking1folks can keep stuff on computers but must learn somethings need to stay offline
12:05 pm
BE12:05pm

@Viking mentions Marriott.

BE12:05pm

https://www.ft.com...-9623-d7f9881e729f

BE12:05pm

The world’s biggest hotel company Marriott International said on Friday the personal details of up to 500m guests were at risk as a result of a massive data breach that had been going on since 2014.

Marriott said its Starwood Hotels & Resorts guest reservation database had been the victim of a “security incident” and had been unlawfully accessed. The database contained the reservation details of up to 500m guests, of which around 327m records listed details including some combination of the person’s name, phone number and passport number among other things.

Viking1 Indeed, somebody might have chosen the wrong tv channel
FATDAZ @Waynej wasn't the acquisition made around the time HP itself was forking into two seperate cos?
Soundbuy Bon w/end all.......
wayneJ @FATDAZ - no - the failed acquisition and the fallout led to the split.
12:06 pm
BE12:06pm

The problem with these stories from an investment perspective -- it's amazingly difficult to predict the market response. Compare, for example, TalkTalk vs IAG.

FATDAZ @wayne I wonder if internal politics or a land grab etc played a role there
BE12:07pm

Former's brand was tarred and feathered; BA was forgotten after a week.

FATDAZ @wayneJ thanks for correcting me
wayneJ OR as HPQ (=printers and PCs) management would say - they got fed up using being used as a cashcow for corporate misadventures and ego investing. (The performance of HPE and DXC and Microfocus (in comparison to HPQ) adds weight to that argument).
BE12:07pm

Which probably reflects how badly these things are reported in the mainstream media, and arguably by the companies themselves.

RAVER thanks @LEMMY
wayneJ May I recommend reading some of the statements by the parties involved. At least those in the public domain suggest that DD was more based on 'trust' and 'I know you - we went to the same college'.
12:09 pm
BE12:09pm

It's always "up to" and "some combination of" .... No idea if passport numbers were salted, very little idea if it was an actual malicious hack or just someone failing to change the server password from admin/tomcat.

BE12:10pm

But all that's a diversion. Let's close this up.

VV75 have a good weekend
BE12:10pm

Thanks all for your several prescient and insightful comments, both today and this week.

Viking1 Good week everybody
wayneJ The big issue for hacks is credit card / financial data and dob + address
12:11 pm
BE12:11pm

There's some Sage, some Thomas Cook and some Renault over here if you want: https://www.ft.com...-ae55-df4bf40f9d0d

Lemmy thanks Bryce
BE12:11pm

Back next week. Afternoon all.
